title.narrative: Strengthening Civil Courage – Sahel

description.narrative: The Sahel has been the scene of large-scale armed conflict since 2012. Jihadist groups, state security forces, international military actors, and community militias and bandits are involved in these armed conflict. The conflict is exacerbated due to conflict between communities and weak state presence. There is economic underdevelopment, clientelism and corruption among elites. The programme in the Sahel will work with civil society actors to address these issues, common security and human rights problems.

The activity is part of a larger programme implemented by the Strengthening Civil Courage Alliance, consisting of ABAAD – Resource Center for Gender Equality, Amnesty International The Netherlands, DefendDefenders, PAX and their partner networks.

The main objective of the Sahel programme is for CSOs and human rights defenders, working in the tri-border region of Mali, Burkina Faso and Niger, to contribute to greater accountability and more inclusive conflict-sensitive policies through effective monitoring and documentation of human rights violations, advocacy, and inclusive dialogue for peace and justice. More specifically, the aim is for CSOs, female and young human rights defenders and activists to claim their civic space; that state actors increasingly respond to the pressure of citizens to build inclusive communities; and, for national governments and international military actors to adhere to international norms and human rights standards.

The main target groups are human rights defenders that work at national level on civic space, good governance and rule of law; human rights defenders involved in monitoring and reporting conflict-related human rights violations; civilian populations and communities in the Liptako Gourma border region; and, CSO partners from the three sides of the border.

participating-org.narrative: ABAAD - Resource Center for Gender Equality

title.narrative: Outcome 1.1: Laws and practices in Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso are favorable to CSOs and create a safe working and legal environment to operate.
# and description of laws and policies improved and/or adopted to safeguard civic space (SCS2)

comment.narrative: 2 existing laws in Mali and Burkina Faso (to improve) and 1 new law in Niger (to introduce). The governments of both Mali and Burkina Faso adopted laws on the protection of HRDs. Currently, there is no legislation on the protection of HRDs in Mali.

The programme strives to advocate the revision of 2 existing laws in Burkina Faso and Mali and the introduction of 1 new law in Niger that expand gender sensitive protection mechanisms for (W)HRDs and safe guard civic space in Sahel.
No laws and policies improved and/or adopted to safeguard civic space in 2021

title.narrative: Capacity development programme partner
# of CSOs with increased L&A capacities

comment.narrative: 7 partners (2 women-led, 2 youth-led, 3 not youth or women-led) analysed their L & A capacities in one or more of 8 capacity areas: A. Produce evidence (4), B Inspiring trust among power holders (2), C. Represent constituency interests (1), D. Analyse the political arena, E. Produce tailored messages (2), F.Work collectively (3), G. Build rapport with power holders (1), H. Adapt to ongoing environmental changes (1), determining their needs to prioritize strengthening these areas.

By the end of 2022, 7 partners (2 women-led, 2 youth-led, 3 not youth or women-led) will have strengthened their L & A capacities in the following capacity areas A. Produce evidence (4), B Inspiring trust among power holders (2), C. Represent constituency interests (1), D. Analyse the political arena, E. Produce tailored messages (2), F. Work collectively (3), G. Build rapport with power holders (1), H. Adapt to ongoing environmental changes (1)

title.narrative: Output 2.2.1 Partner CSOs carry out advocacy initiatives towards holding perpetrators to account
# (and description) of advocacy initiatives carried out by partner CSOs (networks and CSOs) towards new/adjusted/blocked laws, holding perpetrators to account, etc. (SCS4)

comment.narrative: All partners are well connected in civil society in their own countries, including in joint advocacy initiatives, and have a network of national informants. The partners are participating in consultation and advocacy platform with state and non-state actors.

Initiatives with two different kinds of state actors (Ministries of Justice, Defense, Security, Human Rights, National Human Rights Commission, judicial and prosecutoral services, er Relevant Committees of National Parliaments (e.g Committee on Law reform, Committee on Human Rights) of Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger)) per country and one regional initiative . 7 in total
While no advocacy initiatives were undertaken yet, all partner CSOs received capacity-building on lobby and advocacy to prepare for initiatives during the next year.

title.narrative: Programme reach
# of CSOs included in SPs (Strategic Partners) programmes

comment.narrative: Current partner portfolio comprises partner organisations with strong legitimacy at the community-level based on relevant track-records with significant public visibility of actions. All maintain good external relations that afford an important degree of access to authorities for L&A purposes, although activities with regard to the latter require strengthening for a number of partners. Partners were brought together with the aim of developing better coordination and synergy between different organizations and their separate initiatives. Alliance partners either share partner organisations and each strenghten different aspect of L&A advocacy (AINL MDR, PAX community dialogue and external relations, DD safety and security), or they invest in links between partners that are specialised in one of these fields.

Joint learning sessions are foreseen to build bridges between the different partners and thus fulfill the ambition of creating effective synergies. In time this will also be pursued at the regional (cross-country) level.
Written agreements were concluded with seven partner organisations (see CSO partners list)

The ambition to create effective synergies between and strategies of partners will gradually be extended to the regional (cross-country) level over the course of the programme period.

title.narrative: Output 3.1.1 Lobbying and advocacy conducted by CSOs
# (and description of) advocacy actions carried out by CSO partners regarding improving/clarifying legislation/ guidelines on the use of (selected) controversial weapons in the Sahel (SCS4)

comment.narrative: Local civil society has a stronger role to play in stimulating an inclusive public debate on the effects of the use of (selected) controversial weapons on the human rights and security situation of civilians in the Sahel. This finding resulted from an exploratory mission to Niger was carried out by PAX in October 2021 to measure the level of engagement of CSOs on issues surrounding the use of controversial weapons. A follow-up will determine the feasibility of developing joint actions on the issue in collaboration with local CSOs.

If programming proves feasible, by 2025 partner CSOs will have succeeded in stimulating an inclusive debate on the harmful effects of the use of controversial weapons on the human security situation of civilian populations. The feasability and targets will be determined over the course of 2022.
Since this is a new area of work, its feasability remains to be decided.

title.narrative: Outcome 2.1 Governments protect human rights in conflict areas, through new or reformed laws and regulations, including on armed self defence groups
# (and description) of laws, policies blocked, adopted, improved for inclusive peace and justice as a result of CSO engagement (SCS2)

comment.narrative: The persistence of armed violence in conflict areas across the Sahel is sustained by the absence (or harmful nature) of legal and policy frameworks. For example, the government of Burkina Faso passed legislation in January 2021 that enables local authorities to form groups of armed civilians to support state security forces. These have been responsible for civilian deaths and frequent abuses and thus risk exacerbating conflict dynamics.
Two new or reformed laws, regulations or government policies to protect human rights in conflict areas are adapted, in particular on the use of self-defense groups by national governments.

A study was conducted on the unintended consequences of recent legislation enabling the arming of civilians. The study found worrying trends with regards to recruitment patterns, a shifting balance of power in favour of vigilantes, use of illegally procured firearms under the auspices of the government, and cases of abuse of civilians. The study will inform L&A initiatives to demand changes to existing legislation.
